name: Borromean rings
rephrased: Three rings are interlocked such that removing any one causes the others to separate.
implication_form: If three rings are interlocked in the Borromean configuration, then removing any one ring will cause the entire structure to fall apart.
explained: Borromean rings are defined as a specific configuration of three unlinked rings that are interlocked such that the removal of any one ring causes the entire structure to fall apart. This configuration demonstrates a unique form of interdependence where the rings are linked, yet pairwise unlinked. The rings are typically depicted as oval-shaped and arranged symmetrically. Borromean rings are a prime example of a Brunnian link of rank three.
related_conjectures: Conjectures on the properties of Borromean rings in higher dimensions
